articles.headline: From Show and Look to Show and Teach
articles.snippet: Museums are expanding their educational offerings, and finding some very eager students.
articles.abstract: Museums are expanding their educational offerings, and finding some very eager students.
articles.lead_paragraph: THERE have been many strange sightings outside the Whitney Museum of American Art’s Marcel Breuer building over the years: a giant bird’s nest precariously perched on the cantilevered entrance; a neon sign that spelled out “Negro Sunshine”; and a giant replica of a toy fire truck parked at the curb for nearly three months, to name a few. So it is hardly surprising that recent passers-by don’t seem at all curious at the sight of tall black shipping containers rising from the sculpture court.

articles.headline: Rescuing the Stories Behind Latino Art
articles.snippet: “Documents of 20th-Century Latin American and Latino Art,” a new database, offers online access to a trove of valuable materials.
articles.abstract: “Documents of 20th-Century Latin American and Latino Art,” a new database, offers online access to a trove of valuable materials.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of art history’s most telling monuments don’t end up under museum spotlights. They’re found, when and if they’re found, in desk drawers and office file cabinets that no one has cracked in years, or in library stacks, or in jumbles of personal papers boxed up in an artist’s studio.

articles.headline: New iPad: A Polishing of the Old
articles.snippet: The new iPad’s technical improvements keep it at the forefront of desirability — just ahead of the snapping jaws of its Android competition — but don’t take it in any new directions.
articles.abstract: The new iPad’s technical improvements keep it at the forefront of desirability — just ahead of the snapping jaws of its Android competition — but don’t take it in any new directions.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Friday, the new iPad goes on sale. Be sure to ask for it by name: the iPad.

articles.headline: Questions as Banks Increase Dividends
articles.snippet: Stress tests by the Federal Reserve set off a debate among economists and banking analysts about whether banks have actually achieved renewed strength.
articles.abstract: Stress tests by the Federal Reserve set off a debate among economists and banking analysts about whether banks have actually achieved renewed strength.
articles.lead_paragraph: Emboldened by the Federal Reserve’s passing grades on stress tests of banks, some of the nation’s biggest financial firms are racing to dole out billions of dollars in dividends.

articles.headline: Private Businesses Fight Federal Prisons for Contracts
articles.snippet: Critics say competition from Federal Prison Industries, a corporation owned by the government that employs inmates for labor, threatens some jobs on the outside.
articles.abstract: Critics say competition from Federal Prison Industries, a corporation owned by the government that employs inmates for labor, threatens some jobs on the outside.
articles.lead_paragraph: As chief financial officer of a military clothing manufacturer, Steven W. Eisen was accustomed to winning contracts to make garments for the Defense Department.

articles.headline: Women Figure Anew in Senate’s Latest Battle
articles.snippet: Senate Democrats are beginning a push to renew the Violence Against Women Act, the once broadly bipartisan 1994 legislation that now faces fierce opposition from conservatives.
articles.abstract: Senate Democrats are beginning a push to renew the Violence Against Women Act, the once broadly bipartisan 1994 legislation that now faces fierce opposition from conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With emotions still raw from the fight over President Obama’s contraception mandate, Senate Democrats are beginning a push to renew the Violence Against Women Act, the once broadly bipartisan 1994 legislation that now faces fierce opposition from conservatives.

articles.headline: With Arms for Yemen Rebels, Iran Seeks Wider Mideast Role
articles.snippet: While some Yemeni officials are skeptical of the impact of shipments of weapons to the Houthi rebels, American officials see the aid as part of a broader Iranian “shadow war.”
articles.abstract: While some Yemeni officials are skeptical of the impact of shipments of weapons to the Houthi rebels, American officials see the aid as part of a broader Iranian “shadow war.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the past several months, Iran appears to have increased its political outreach and arms shipments to rebels and other political figures in Yemen as part of what American military and intelligence officials say is a widening Iranian effort to extend its influence across the greater Middle East.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Robert F. Worth

articles.headline: Karzai Calls on U.S. to Pull Back as Taliban Cancel Talks
articles.snippet: Prospects for an orderly NATO withdrawal from Afghanistan suffered two setbacks as President Hamid Karzai demanded limits on United States troops and the Taliban halted peace talks.
articles.abstract: Prospects for an orderly NATO withdrawal from Afghanistan suffered two setbacks as President Hamid Karzai demanded limits on United States troops and the Taliban halted peace talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai insisted Thursday that the United States confine its troops to major bases in Afghanistan by next year as the Taliban announced that they were suspending peace talks with the Americans, both of which served to complicate the Obama administration’s plans for an orderly exit from the country.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland, Elisabeth Bumiller and Matthew Rosenberg
